body: Well toree on master doesn't support 2.10 afaik

Ok, personally I'm all in favor of dripping support for the eol scala 2.10.
I was just checking because spark still supports it.

As far as I know the version of akka we are using right now is also scala 2.11+

@jodersky, @mariusvniekerk, I'm using a gradle-based build instead of sbt. Are you guys interested in having a gradle build script available in addition to sbt? I find it easier to work with and it matches our other projects. I completely understand if you only want one build, but I thought I'd offer since I have it working.
It looks like the build is failing, but not from this patch. The scala tests are all passing. I'm also happy to add a test for this, if someone can tell me where it should go.
@jodersky Okay for me to merge this in or do you still have some things you want to add to this?
Looks good to me.  All relevant tests are passing.  The failure is due to a missing apache header in the gitattributes file so nothing major.
@rdblue, have you opened a PR for it? If not, do so. We can take a look to see how much effort it would be to maintain.
@mariusvniekerk good to go!
I recommend we close this PR in favor of #104
agreed
Yes of course, didn't think about that. LGTM pending ci and conflicts then
@chipsenkbeil, I opened PR #106 with the gradle build script. I hope it's useful.
LGTM. @rdblue, would you mind rebasing? Once you do, I'll merge this in.

@chipsenkbeil, I've rebased and will watch to see if there are test issues. Thanks for reviewing this!

If you have a chance to look at my other small pull requests (not #104, that's not ready to merge), I'd appreciate that as well. They're useful changes that were blockers for us moving to tests with users.

@rdblue, no problem. I'll take a look at the other ones today. If possible, I'd need you to rebase those as I prepare to merge them. This allows our Apache bot to mark the PR as merged. We don't have administrative access over the repository; so, we cannot merge/close PRs on our own.

I'll mention you on each PR as I go through them.

Thanks @chipsenkbeil!

You might have more flexibility than you'd think with the integration between Apache infra and github. I've pushed commits to Avro and had it correctly detected that it was a merge. I'm not sure if that had to be a fast-forward or not, but I thought it didn't.

You can also close a PR by adding "closes #103" to the commit message. That's how our [merge script](https://github.com/apache/parquet-mr/blob/master/dev/merge_parquet_pr.py) for Parquet works (which we took from Spark). It squashes all of the commits from the PR and builds a commit message that will close it.
I forgot to mention: I'm happy to rebase my PRs, just let me know which one you want to look at next.

@rdblue, thanks for the tip about closing! I tried it before, but must have done something wrong because it didn't close the PR. As for merging, we've been told to rebase as much as possible to keep a clean commit log. Maybe a merge commit would aid in closing the PR? Regardless, if you're able to rebase, that'll be a big help!
Travis seems to be doing nothing at the moment. I'd rather get these items in and repair any damage with additional commits later. So, going to merge.

A merge commit might work, but I dislike using them. I'd much rather have rebases than merges since it is so much easier to revert. I think the question is whether the integration will pick up on cherry-picked commits or rebases on your end, or just fast-forward. That's how I merge everything in Avro, but I often forget to add the bit to close PRs.
@rdblue, that I've seen, the integration does not pick up on rebases that I conduct myself. I don't know about cherry-picked commits.
@rdblue, can you rebase this one next?
Done.
Sorry, missed the `startingWhiteSpace` method you added. Also, not sure if this will affect any of our Jupyter tests for the kernel. Really wish Travis would do its job. :/
Added another comment to #98. While that one gets updated, can you rebase this one? I'll merge this one in first since it's a one-liner.
I added a comment for the regex and ran tests (with gradle). All of them are passing.
Rebased.
LGTM
Thanks for merging this, @mariusvniekerk!
Okay, LGTM. Do you have time to rebase this one more time? Otherwise, I'll try to do the close trick tomorrow morning. I'll get to the other PRs tomorrow as well.
Rebased.
LGTM
@mariusvniekerk, does this look good to you? If so, @rdblue, can you rebase this?
Thanks for all your help today, @chipsenkbeil!
Rebased
Okay looks good to me.  I think we did this initially to limit the size of the classes that got generated.  However the quality of life improvement that this gives is worth it IMO.
There may be other tricks we can do to reduce the generated classes as well, so I'll merge this in. Thanks @rdblue and @mariusvniekerk!
Thank you @chipsenkbeil and @mariusvniekerk for reviewing!

I agree that we would have to replace `BuildInfo`; I just didn't want to go to the trouble unless there was interest in a gradle-based build. My main motivation is to see if anyone else is interested so we don't do the same work twice, not necessarily to convince everyone to move to gradle.

The benefits I like are:
* Gradle appears to be faster. If I run from a cleaned directory with no gradle daemon running, the build with tests takes under 3 minutes. With sbt (make build test), the build takes just under 7 minutes.
* There is a single build script that is easy to follow. I find sbt builds hard to read, but gradle is reasonably straight-forward.
* Gradle is easier to use (in my opinion) and has good support for tasks like dependency inspection.

So we've recently refactored the sbt piece of toree.  

As long as this still produces the ivy XML pieces needed to play nice with coursier and dependency fetching I have no objections.
Will this correct the same issue on toree 0.1.0.dev8 for Spark 1.X ?

I don't know anything about the coursier requirements you mentioned, so I doubt it works. Are you talking about using Coursier for compile time dependency management, or for runtime downloads? We don't intend to have users download dependency trees at runtime, so I didn't really look into it.

@rdblue, we generate Ivy XML describing the different modules of Toree (kernel, kernel-api, communication, etc). The reason we do this is to use it with our dynamic dependency downloader used in `%%AddDeps`. We do this to avoid adding the same jar more than once for the compile classpath and runtime classloader used for interpreting Scala code.

The relevant code to generate the Ivy XML files is https://github.com/apache/incubator-toree/blob/master/project/CommonPlugin.scala#L47
The relevant code to load the Ivy XML files and use them for exclusions is https://github.com/apache/incubator-toree/blob/master/kernel-api/src/main/scala/org/apache/toree/dependencies/CoursierDependencyDownloader.scala#L286

This is purely for adding dependencies at runtime.

@rdblue FYI, I'm all for easier and faster. If you want to work on tackling the Ivy generation and making sure it plays well with our dependency downloaders, I'll try to pitch a little.

I'm at the airport right now and flying off to http://scalasphere.org for the week, but I'll be around some next week if needed.

It won't work out-the-box for older versions; we'd need to back port it to 0.1.x branch.

@chipsenkbeil do you think this is something that could make it into 0.1.x?
So for 0.1 users can start with - - nosparkcontext and then construct their own sparkconf.  This allows setting the application name
@mariusvniekerk I was thinking about this solution. Thank you anyway!
The build failure seems to be unrelated, `make system-test` fails (this happens on master as well) but unit tests pass.
LGTM, thanks @jodersky
What does this change?

This binds `spark` before this runs:

```
    logger.info("Marking relay as ready for receiving messages")
    kernelMessageRelayActor ! true
```

That way if a cell was submitted during kernel startup, it can't run and fail. This prevents the interpreter hanging, which is a larger issue described on TOREE-389.
Ah, yeah that's a pain.

You can force it by closing and reopening the PR

I realize that changing the tests is not ideal but I think it is required.  I don't believe the ids should be treated as strings.  What I want to know is if I can do this at all ( make ids Array[Byte] ) or if it is a breaking change and allso, if there is a better approach.
I say changing the test is fine. For me the real test is to make sure that all is still working when connecting the notebook. I'm going to give that a try here... (now that I can build!).

LGTM with minor removal of .setAppName(SparkKernelInfo.banner)

I'll fix the name problem, but there's an additional problem with this before we can merge it. Some of the plugins like AddDeps and AddJar depend on the Spark context via IncludeSparkContext. I think this should remove that class if we are no longer going to send the events. Otherwise, the context is always null and AddDeps breaks.
Thanks for the quick reply @rdblue , I will wait for the next updates from you then.

I've extracted the displayer registration from this PR and created an independent project for it: https://github.com/rdblue/jupyter-repr-api

The idea is to make it so that libraries have a standard way to provide code to display objects, without relying on a specific kernel implementation.
@kevin-bates @rdblue, could you see if the double-inclusion error persists after a `git clean`? Changes to the build occasionally cause `sbt clean` to miss things
@lresende , @lbustelo .  I think I'm ready for review now.  Thanks.  /J

Thanks @jodersky.  I'm confident `git clean` resolves that issue, although I'm not in a position to try it since its a one-time need following the pull of the sbt changes.  I mentioned this in an earlier comment in this PR and given it helped move @lbustelo forward for PR #111, I suspect @rdblue is good to go - but I'll have to defer to him.

I've updated this PR and removed the IncludeSpark* classes that are no longer notified since Spark is lazily initialized. These were only used for AddDeps and AddJars, which now pass the new Jar URIs to the kernel rather than working directly with Spark. Eventually, I think we should move to a SparkKernel implementation that layers on the Spark methods if it is enabled.

I also removed the appName call, so this no longer conflicts with #107.

Using git to clean up after sbt appears to have worked, but now tests are failing with an OOM. Maybe Travis will work this time...

LGTM, verified trough few notebook examples and restart scenarios.
Merging if there are no more comments
@lresende Do you know when there will be another 0.2.0 (pre)release?
I would recommend you building it yourself from master.

This is a very neat plugin! Considering it is project-agnostic and IMO provides useful functionality for every sbt project, it is probably a good idea to add this as a global sbt plugin (in `~/.sbt/0.13/plugins/plugins.sbt`). It won't do any harm to include it in Toree either though, but then we'd need to keep it up to date.
Are there any further features or processes in Toree (i.e. build or release pipeline), that assume `sbt dependencyTree` to be available?
LGTM
What's up with the CI failure? It seems unrelated.
No, it's mostly used for troubleshooting or as a helper for dependency information gathering.
Ok, as I mentioned above, this makes a fine global plugin however I don't have any objections in including this in Toree either. So LGTM
@kevin-bates, looks like there is a compile failure. Can you fix it and push an update?

Should this be configurable? Maybe through a command line option? Or do you guys think that the `Console.out` channel should be removed entirely?

@lbustelo, @Lull3rSkat3r, @mariusvniekerk, is this is a transient failure? Can't remember.

https://travis-ci.org/apache/incubator-toree/builds/211856830#L3626

I guess I can see some benefit for debugging - especially as we get into remote kernel scenarios (which is happening).  However, I've also been around enough to know that even the slightest existence of sensitive data persisted in places it shouldn't go can be considered a serious security concern.  Since we have no control over what an end user wishes to output in their notebook, then I'm more of the opinion that we should not permit its capture at all. 
I don't believe other kernels/interpreters (including those in Toree) perform this kind of capture either.  So for that there's precedent as well.
Haven't seen that one @chipsenkbeil
@rdblue So the AddJarSpec test failures are probably the spark context not being around yet.
